description.text:
This switch design requires a 6mm momentary push button switch and 4 3mm leds. I needed a needed a momentary switch that had 4 ack/state feedback indications so this was made. LEDs could always be wired up or configured how ever is needed, easy to set up with something like an arduino. I printed top, bottom, and ring in black and then printed the button in clear, maybe white would work - or a thin layer or two of white with the rest clear. Switch is pressed into/onto bottom facing inner so the button will press down on it and leds are inserted from the bottom so they protrude into the switch body.
Have fun.
It is a unfinished pencil holder that should hold 5 staedtler pencils.

RM 2.54 / Breadboard Socket for ESP8266 ESP-03 or ESP-04.
Provided as is.
May need 0.25 nozzle or smaller.
Printed with 0.2mm layer height, 0.25mm extrusion width.
Holes don't go through! Holes that small won't print fine on my printbed, so the first layer is compact. Use 1mm drill or just a hot cable to drill through. Instructions:
  • Print ;)
  • Drill/clean holes
  • fix socket to breadboard with ~2cm long ~0.6mm thick wires
  • bend wires 90° to the center
  • fix wires with glue
  • cut remaining wires ~3mm long and bend down ~80°

Mount for attaching a phone or tablet to a RigidBot. This allows you to easily use an old phone as a webcam, time lapse recorder etc.  
Made to allow most size phones, and even tablets - no height or width restriction.  
Prepared with a lip to allow LED strips (which will also light up the RigidBot Community logo nicely), but will make a good fit otherwise as well.  
Made with Tinkercad .

• iPhone 5
  • Samsung Galaxy Note 4 (see photo)
  • Samsung Galaxy S5
  • Samsung Galaxy S4
  • ZTE Blade III

• Samsung Galaxy Tab Pro 10.1 (see photo)
  • Asus Eee Pad TF101 (weighs 680g!)

Can use thicker devices (v1.0=10mm, v1.1=12mm) and has larger slots. Center slot can be used for devices with lens very close to bottom edge, such as upside-down tablets. Also added reinforcements so that the larger slots don't make for a weaker construction.

Model is pre-rotated so you can print as is.  
To attach to printer frame, start from the inner edge (as if phone is laying flat) and push down. Will snap in place and stay there.  
I printed the mount in the picture with ABS, 25% infill, using brim and support. Feels very solid, but can use even more infill if you have a very heavy tablet.  
If you have a very slippery device and are worrying about it shaking loose due to vibrations, simply put a rubberband around the lower edge. This will give your device a non-slip "floor". Or just leave some of the brim.

author: sharkbot

description.text:
I always want to try to mount my Prusa i3 Z axis upside down, mostly due my version is boxed and is terribly difficult to change the NEMA's Z motors.
And so... There it is, my new Z Up2Down system, with sigle or dual anti-wobble, z couplers and it works! I'm open to modifications, and is suitable for Prusa i3 sigle plate and stabilized versions, both in 6mm versions, with 8mm smooth rods and 5mm threaded rods. It requires 2 additional holes per side in the plates, but is optional (indeed very recomended). Depending on your Prusa i3 flavour, the 8mm smooth rod and the 5mm threaded rod could result a little shorter. My friend resolved it making 2 additional holes in the plate to fix the down side in the plate.

Print at least @0.2mm layer and 70% infill, minimum 3 perimeters.
If sliced with Slic3r v1.2.1, use the XYSizeCompensation using the formula:
XYCompensation = NozzleDiameter / 2
So if u have a 0.35mm Nozzle Diameter, then the compensation will be 0.175mm. That's due to Slic3r calculation that trace the filament in his center, not withinn his diameter once extruded (not true, but believe me, is quite needed). For the top motor holder, there are 2 versions. One with a tower that will carry the BallBearing to maximize the anti-wobbling system and the other without it. Print the first one ONLY if u are a lucky owner of a dual extrusion systemand of some PVA filament. Is quite difficult to print using support without PVA. BOM:
2/4x BB625ZZ (id 5mm - od16mm - ht 5mm)
6x 3x10 bolts
6x 3mm nuts
10/12x 3x25 bolts
10/12x 3mm nuts

author: Karen5R

title: Rigidbot Community LCD cover with bracket.

description.text:
The Front cover is from Walter's design, I just added 0.5mm to the front thickness as I found the bezel around the LCD was too thin for my liking.  Also increased the size by 0.5%.  The LCD fit at the original, but was a bit tight if you need to remove it for any reason.  
The brackets mount to the holes on the Rigidbot front panel, I did not use any nuts to back up the 4mm screws, just threaded them straight into the panel.  
The backcover has 4mm wells to receive 4mm nuts.  It's a tight fit so I suggest positioning the nut in place and using a screw to fully seat it.  
The cable cover is a simple clip on affair that holds the PCB and covers all the exposed solder joints.  
I also made buttons from Walter's thing with .5mm added to keep them flush.  One has an E for E-Stop, one with S for Select, and one blank.  Since E can be confused for Enter and S for Stop, I'm open to better suggestions!  
Thanks Walter for the original design and Marvin for the LCD project!   
Update: Added a STOP button I made yesterday before leaving work.  I have not printed it so I have no idea if the feature size of the lettering will work or not.  Print at your own risk!  
Updated Update: The lettering is too small for a 0.4mm nozzle.  The octagon with print without lettering.
Nothing special, think I covered it all in the Description.

comments.text:
LCD frame fits perfectly!, but the buttons are a tad too big, scale down 0.95 for perfect fit.
as for symbols, * for light, ! for reset
edit: I just noticed the holes in frame for stop and jog control not quite centered, the stop button will be an issue.
I have the Sainsmart 12684 full graphic LCD, yellow.

comments.text: Keep in mind that the front cover here is 0.5% larger than the original, but I would agree there seems to be some variability in the board builds so it would make a lot of sense to measure your board first before printing to determine if you need to scale it up further. Unfortunately I don't remember what my height and width dimensions are and I'm won't be back to work to check until Monday.

comments.text:
I would use ! For stop (it is usually inside a triangle). How about a light bulb for the light button (I don't use it and have jumpered it always be on). Select is by pressing on the rotary switch.
The height of the LCD is an assembly of two boards. Depending on how your LCD panel was assembled at the factory, the dimension will vary. My LCD measured 91mm tall and 93mm wide. The first switch on the right measured about 11mm left of the right side of the LCD board. There should be a bit of tolerance allowed for factory LCD assembly variations.?

description.text:
Making text for Unicorn or EggBot plots isn't always a fun process. Most tools require you to convert text into paths, and even then you get the outlines of shapes, which can often turn messy at small sizes. mifga pointed me towards the Hershey fonts[1]. They're a set of fonts for vector plotters named after creator Dr. A. V. Hershey who made them for the National Bureau of Standards. These files are in a weird, weird, format. But after some normalizing, wailing, and gnashing of teeth, I was able to write some code to parse them and spit them back out as SVG! Now you can use these fonts in your Unicorn drawings. Each SVG contains a layout of one of the Hershey fonts. The hershey_svg.zip file below contains all of the SVG files. The hershey.zip file contains the (cleaned up) original .jhf files. math-drawing.svg is just an example of using these glyphs, including scaling and stretching. I think the result is nice! To use these in Unicorn plots, you'll want to grab my Unicorn G-Code extension for Inkscape[2]. [1] Hershey fonts - http://emergent.unpythonic.net/software/hershey
[2] Unicorn output for Inkscape - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5986

To use these fonts in your Unicorn plots:
  • Download the SVG file containing the font of your choice, or grab the whole hershey_svg.zip to get them all.
  • In your Inkscape drawing, use File | Import to load the font you want
  • Drag around and duplicate the characters that you want to use.
  • Delete the ones that you don't.
    5a. (Unicorn users) Save your file and Save a Copy to get your .gcode!
    5b. (EggBot users) Plot directly from Inkscape. :)

title: Team Blackout Spider Hex Sonar Mount

description.text: So here is a mount for the ultrasonic module HC-SR04 fitting on your spider hex copter. First I wanted to make the mount in front of the copter, but if you are using a gopro, this won't work together. So I decided to build a mount for the back. Using a NAZE32 FC and Baseflight or Cleanflight firmware and you're happy.

Just enable "supporting material" to get best printing results.
After print, u can pull it on the back withoud any screws. You only need some screws to mount the sonar module to the mount. Alternatively you can fix the sonar module with hot glue...

author: aikon96

description.text:
Non trovando in commercio il ricambio, ho deciso di farne uno compatibile, non è uguale, ma funziona.
In particolare ho evitato di lasciare il buco come nell'originale, visto che dei ragni hanno pensato bene di fare il loro nido.
Per la stampa consiglio di usare 0,2 come risoluzione e di impostare l'uso di materiale di supporto, in quanto, il gancio, la parte più importante, ne ha bisogno, per il resto non ci sono problemi di stampa.
Come materiale ho usato il PLA, meglio sarebbe farlo in ABS così da rendere il pezzo più duraturo e meno fragile.

Stampate lo zoccolo DX o SX a seconda di quale dovete sostituire.
Stampatelo dritto con il fondo appoggiato sul piatto di stampa.
Impostate Risoluzione 0,2 e Materiale di supporto, Riempimento almeno al 50%, anche si vi consiglio 60% o altre.
Recuperate il bullone dall'originale, prendete 2 dadi M4, inseritene uno sul fondo dell'apposito foro esagonale, l'altro avvitatelo al bullone in modo che una volta inserito in sede rimanga più in alto nel foro e avvitate quanto basta.
Rimontate lo zoccolo così sistemato.

description.text: MilkyWeigh lets you know when it's time to buy milk! It connects to ChillHub via USB, measures the weight of the milk jug and it can be programmed to notify you when you are running low. The MilkyWeigh housing was designed to be 3D printed. We are making a Sensor Kit available so people can print and assemble their own MilkyWeigh! Find out more about ChillHub and MilkyWeigh here: https://firstbuild.com/bpwagner/chillhub/ The housing design has 2 parts, a bottom and the top. There are 2 versions of each. The "flat" parts are optimized for printing without support material.
To build the electronics: https://upverter.com/firstbuild/9f340f5f74da9da4/ChillHub-MilkMinder/ Software: https://github.com/FirstBuild

The final version will be v3 and the entire case will be 3d printed, the overall size will be really minimised, for geting a final project smaller than a regular gamecube. The project will be sold a day (and many others) on our website : http://ihpu0.free.fr/ Edit 29/01/2016:

This is an assortment of cable chain mounts- I'm trying different configurations to find one that I like. The various part revisions are different mounting options for each cable chain end.   
I've included the Solidworks 2014 files for your modification needs. 
2015.11.17 Update: I added two additional mount types. The new mounts were created in Solidworks 2016

Use M4 x 12mm FHS and M4 nuts to attach the drag chain end to the printed mount. Use M5 SHCS & nuts to attach the mounts to the Shapeoko.  
I printed these in ABS, 0.2mm layer, 50% fill, no support. YMMV.

author: ChooseHappy777

description.text: A few months ago I purchased a set of Aaron Tunell's filament monitors that were posted here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:345216 Now, I knew that my mounting arrangement was going to be significantly different, because I long ago axed the rear mounted spools, and mounted them overhead, feeding straight down. This also got rid of the guide tubes. Also, I have the excellent acrylic hood made by Dave Randolph here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23386 With this hood, and the spools overhead (or sitting on rollers on the hood itself), I just feed the filament through the slot left where the top and slanted front of the hood pieces meet. So where to mount the monitors? The answer seems to be, on the hood, fixed in that same slot. Though I haven't gotten the monitors wired in yet (need to extend cables), it seems to feed very well.

This was one of the rare (for me) occurrences where the thing went from OpenSCAD, to print, and installed; all in one shot.  I can't think of anything I'd want to change at the moment.  It prints easily; I used a 0.15 layer height and 12% infil, printed with Simplify3D, in ABS.  
The cable connecting the two monitors needs be be bent backwards, so that it extends behind the monitors.  Alternately, it could just be shortened, if you have the soldering skills.  The data cable needs to be extended to reach the Mightyboard, and while doing that, it would be a good idea to add an inline connector to allow the hood to be removed and the monitors unplugged so they don't have to be removed from the hood.  I still need to find some cable clamps to dress the cable.  
The monitors mount with four, M3-10 cap screws; pretty obvious.  The mounting then just sits in the slot, with front and rear tabs to stabilize it.  A bit of double sided tape is probably a good idea, to stick it in place to the top of the hood.  
There are three 3mm holes in the back edge of the mount.  They are there to mount a rear cover in case I decide it's necessary (I really dislike exposed electronics).  
I mentioned that I'd gotten rid of the guide tubes; well, while it's in a bit of disarray at the moment, you can see that I've also gotten rid of the extruder top plate.  It's remarkably heavy, and it's main purpose was to hold the guide tubes.  It also provided support for the cable bundle, but I can add in something much lighter that can do that.  (And yes, I have one extruder removed at the moment.)  
To anticipate a question, yes, the carriage motion does drag the filament off the spool, but I have yet to see any print artifact that I can attribute to this extra drag.

title: Prusa i3 LCD mounts for 6mm sheet frame

description.text: I designed these mounts for my new prusa i3 with a 6mm thick acrylic sheet frame, but this would also fit on anything 6mm thick

made in autodesk, highly recommended to be printed on its side, the 3mm holes printed fine for me, and i used 3m*12 bolts and nuts, and the nuts are held in place by cutouts on the print to make assembly a breeze

comments.text: same printer, same supplier, same problems;

Just got a Sunhokey and switching to Cura has improved my print quality drastically with PLA I'm printing at 175 and the bed at 55. Speed in Cura is 35mm/s.
Biggest thing was calibrating E steps and increasing retraction speed to 45 mm/s with a length of 6mm its cleaned up the prints with a lot less oozing.
Still playing around with settings but I'm happy with it right now, was able to print that fully assembled cresent wrench (working) with Cura after 2 failed attempts with Slic3r (ended up all fused together) but printing time is longer it seems though.
Same with cura.  60mm is okay with me, if you take care to slow down for top/bottom and outer shell speed

title: Servo Bracket mount HC-SR04 Ultrasonic Sensor

description.text: Mounting bracket for the SainSmart HC-SR04 ultrasonic transducer PCB (one version of a "ping" distance sensor). Two models; one generic and one to fit a servo horn that comes with the Hitec HS-311 servo. The board just drops into a slot and is not fixed in place with screws, so it can be quickly removed. Fits equally well the other way (sensors facing away from servo arm). Please note there are at least two different "HC-SR04" boards out there, I know one type from ebay has different dimensions by a few mm and would need modifications to the OpenSCAD file to fit. I used 3x M2 screws as self-tapping into the 1.5 mm holes in the servo arm, first using a M2 drill to ream out the matching 3 holes in the bracket. You may prefer to adjust the size of the holes in the SCAD file, depending on your hardware. If you want a more rigidly fixed PCB, you may prefer this one: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:100486

author: tjmcquitty

description.text:
Simple flying bases because I had Deffkopta's without bases.  Printed on "clear" filament, which makes sort of an interesting ice/snow effect.  
Note

This is "just" the base.  I included a picture of a Deffkopta on the base to show how it might be used.  
Support Me Please
Sort of a random thing, but if you like my stuff please check out my Lego R2-D2's blog at http://L3-G0.com or L3-G0's Youtube, and please tweet of facebook a link to his page, every visitor helps!

Print one or more bases and one or more posts (since I printed them they can be different heights!)  
Hints

• The posts didn't print very well without some support, and the slicer didn't support well, so you may want "7 posts with support" - I used a raft.
  • The supports are tiny & tricky, so I had to clean them up. YMMV.
  • I included the rounded 60mm base w/o hole as well. Don't print that if you plan to jam a support in it!
  • Included random scad files used to make these.
  • You might try printing the post with the base. I printed them individually because I planned to mail them.
    • Support Me Please
Sort of a random thing, but if you like my stuff please check out my Lego R2-D2's blog at http://L3-G0.com or L3-G0's Youtube, and please tweet of facebook a link to his page, every visitor helps!

author: zMath

description.text:
This is the NASA file, downloaded directly from the NASA site. "Uplink.stl" is the name given to the file by NASA.
http://nasa3d.arc.nasa.gov/detail/wrench-mis Again, from NASA, the ratchet wrench designed by Noah Paul-Gin was uploaded and printed as a working ratchet wrench. The original dimensions - as printed in space - 4.48-inch-long by 1.29-inch wide.The 3D Made in Space Printer is used in a micro-gravity environment with standard additive manufacturing, depositing 104 layers of ABS plastic. ... I have printed five fully-functioning models (see Instructions page). Profguy has moved and you can find other fun items in our shop: http://www.3DBodyJewelry.com

Printed with an ancient Solidoodle 2A Pro using NO SUPPORT on 6x6 bed. Scale is 1:1. Protoparadigm ABS filament, 200/95C. My working models required 0.1mm layer deposit, at 60% infill. 4hr. print-time. Hints: if your bed is anywhere out of level, plum, or square just forget it, fuses into a mess. Printing with a support, raft, or brim only causes melting of the first three layers and prevents the mechanism from working.
At a 40% infill and 0.3mm layer a nice (working) model took my Solidoodle about 1.5hrs.

comments.text: We know what he meant. But thanks for the link:)

comments.text: The Made in Space printer does not create a microgravity environment. It was designed to be used in a microgravity environment, such as already exists in the ISS. For reference: https://www.google.com/search?q=3D+Made+in+Space+Printer+micro-gravity+environment

author: ibraud

description.text:
Boom! The perfect print for all your needs! This 3D Printable mug promises a comfortable sip and is easy to wash up! << CAUTION >>
Not suitable for hosting warm / hot beverages, especially when using ABS. Ensure to wash the mug thoroughly before using, and make sure there are no loose strands of filament before drinking from. It's probably not very practical. Supports are not necessary but use them for a safer print. Also make sure you print it as a solid entity as if sections are hollow, water can seep through into them. 3D printers aren't the best at making water-tight containers when using hollow settings! Have fun!
~ Michael

It's dangerous to celebrate New Year's Eve alone! Take this.  
Today is my awesome cousin Sergio's birthday! In celebration of one of the first 3D models we printed together (and one of my favorite games of all time), I designed a fancy Triforce pendant.  
With a little bit of sanding, primer, and gold paint, you too can make it as bling as the original NES cartridge that your mom gave away when you were on vacation on summer and she was just "cleaning" around the house. (NEVER FORGET. (?_?) )  
FYI: I almost called this pendant, "Legend of Sergio". Almost.

Takes ~21min to print on my Makerbot Rep2 on high settings 15% in-fill, 2 shells, .10mm. To add fancy +1:
  • Sand with emery nail file
  • Spray with Filler Primer
  • Spray with gold paint of choice

remixed_from.author: IvanOwen
remixed_from.title: Socket & tip for custom partial finger replacement

description.text:
See newer models by Knick:
Version 3.5: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1340624
Version 3.0: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:904304
Version 2.0: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:586012 This is my first finger attempt, and first wearable model, which borrowed heavily from Flexi-hand and Ivan's finger. I like the smoothness of motion of the flexi-hinges. However I find that fixed hinges can be tweaked to the right tension easier, and have a more positive feeling movement. With this model I hot-glued the stump to the socket, which was a common failure point after about a week of usage, leading to the snap-in design I did later.
I'll add more complete instructions if anyone requests them.  See version 2.0 for the latest model, with more complete instructions.

My wife commissioned a blunt needle so that she could teach my daughter to weave a "rag rug" (aka "knot rug" or "amish rug").  I threw this together with Open Scad printed off a few. The default is about the same diameter as a pen or pencil. She gave one or two away to some women in her lunch time crafting group. So far no one has asked for a refund. ;)  
The SCAD file is parametric so you can tweak it to fit your needs.
To print you'll want to rotate it down on it's side and oriented so the hole is open to the top/bottom.  I printed with a 5mm brim to keep it stuck down but no support.

title: Yaesu FT-7800 Remote Face Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: In a crazy collision of technologies, this is a mount for a removable (remote) face for a dual-band Ham radio made by Yaesu. Problem: How to mount the remote face of my new radio in my Prius without drilling any holes? Bonus for easy removal! Before you get too far... even if you ARE a licensed Ham, odds are you don't need a mount to fit an FT-7800. However, I am very satisfied with how this came out, and maybe it can inspire you to solve a similar problem. I have a silly little rubberish doohickey that fits into my cup holder, called a "Cellcup" and is designed to hold a smartphone in addition to pens and maybe a chapstick. LInk: http://www.amazon.com/Commutemate-Cell-Electronics-Holder-Black/dp/B001RUW4GU/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1363248094&sr=8-2&keywords=cellcup This mount mimics the dimensions of a smart phone such that it can fit into this rubber insert and hold the face of the radio and microphone in a convenient location on the center console of my Prius. MORE PHOTOS: http://www.flickr.com/photos/theschlem/sets/72157632996764258/

ATTENTION
This work is licensed under the Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial license. This license applies only to the files and documents available for download from the Thing Files section of this Thing.
All other related content (photographs, videos, and verbiage such as contained in "Description" or "Instructions" ) are excluded from this license. with all rights reserved, unless specifically available for download This notice constitutes a clarification, not a change, to licensing for this design.

Small holes in the adapter plate are 1/8 inch; the larger holes are 9/64 inch.  You will want to drill them out to proper size.  The smaller holes fit 4-40 screws, and the larger fit 6-32 screws.  
I stuck a rubber washer on one side of the joint between the mount and the phone-shaped insert to allow a small preload to keep the face from rotating.  You may have a better solution. Please share if so.  
I have no idea what other radio faces may fit this adapter plate, but feel free to remix it to your needs. Or you can just glue it to the back of your radio face mounting plate.  I won't be offended.  
The inside measurement of the mount on top of the "cell phone simulacrum" is 37.5mm.  If you want a rubber washer or O-ring for friction, adjust your mounting plate accordingly. Contact me if I can answer any questions.

title: HerringBone Extruder Gear Prusa i3 Rework

description.text:
I tweaked the scad parameters and exported each gear individually in order to improve the printing parameters per gear. Specifically I have changed the distance between axles to 41mm.
Beware that these gears are 11/45 and the standard gears that came with my Prusa i3 Rework is 10/43. So you will need to adjust your extruder steps per unit by calculating the ratio difference: 10x45 / (11x43) = 450 / 473 Make sure you line up the gears well before tightening. I did this by first fastening the large gear and leaving the small gear loose on the motor axle. Then I spun the large gear around and tightened the small gear between the two extremes I found. This way the front of both gears are about flush with each other.

I have printed these gears in PLA with 0.5mm nozzle. Adjust the temperatures as needed for you particular setup. I have printed the small gear with concentric infill, which works well for the gear part, but I would recommend rectilinear for the hub (tophalf) because it created a gap with my settings. You can also choose 100% infill of course. I also ended up with an open top, so 2 solid top layers will probably do the trick to fix that. Small gears:
print time: 1:40:14
layer height: 0.1mm
printspeed: 15mm/s
infill: 90% concentric
minimum perimeters: 0
solid fill top & bottom: 3
fan: 50% all the way starting on layer 3 (100% bridges)
bed temp first layer: 60
bed temp: 55
extruder temp first layer: 200C
extruder temp: 190C Large gears:
print time: 3:05:08
layer height: 0.1mm
printspeed: 30mm/s
infill: 90% concentric
minimum perimeters: 0
solid fill top: 2
solid bottom: 1
fan: 60% all the way starting on layer 3 (100% on bridges)
bed temp first layer: 60
bed temp: 50
extruder temp first layer: 200C
extruder temp: 190C The large gear lifted off the bed on one end, but came out very nice on the second run.

After another pair of links failed - one broke off at the base and the other end just kept slipping out, I came up with these.
I've been using these to print successfully. No slippage, and easy to take the bowden tube out when making changes to the hot end.
I've also got a jhead groove-mount to bowden one piece to upload at some point, which also works really well.

Vitamins:
8 x 20mm M3 bolts
8 x M3 locknuts
6mm OD 3mm ID PTFE bowden tube.
3mm/6mm drill bit Instructions:
Print the part twice.
Clean the parts.
Insert one end of the bowden tube in to the mount. Drill through one hole to groove the edge of the tube. Insert a bolt. Repeat for the remaining 3 holes.
Install on printer and print :) Update:
I printed with these last night, and everything was successful.
Now just to recalibrate my retraction & print speeds :)

This is another cooling design, inspired by (but not directly based on) thing 5756.
I wanted to use Iwo's design, but I just upgraded to a MakerGear stepper plastruder on my Thing-o-Matic, and there wasn't enough clearance around the extruder nozzle to mount any fan ducts on the top side of the Z-stage. So, this design is a circular cooling nozzle that mounts around the extruder nozzle, just under the Z-stage.
It is fed by two 1/4" PVC hoses, attached to a fan mount that sits on top of the Z-stage, near the rear of the bot. This mount holds a 40mm fan salvaged from an old graphics card.
The overall airflow is very subtle- it's detectable with your hand, but just barely. But it makes a huge difference in print quality for small parts. In the attached image of two single-wall calibration boxes, both boxes were printed consecutively using the same g-code. The only difference is that one box had the cooling fan intake blocked.
This design is in parametric OpenSCAD, so it should be fairly easy to adapt to other nozzle types or fan sizes.
Note: This adds some extra hardware to the underside of your Z-stage. Make sure there will be clearance with anything you have sticking up from your build platform. I had to remove the nozzle wiper from my ABP. (The wiper wasn't working very well with my MakerGear nozzle anyway, so no big loss...)

• If you aren't using a MakerGear extruder, adjust the OpenSCAD sources for your nozzle geometry

  • Measure your fan, and adjust the OpenSCAD sources for its radius.

  • Print both parts. Be aware of the overhangs- the nozzle has 40 degree overhangs throughout, and the tubing barbs can be difficult to print correctly. You shouldn't need to enable support material. The only support necessary is under the hose barb, and it's been added explicitly by the OpenSCAD sources.

  • Using a sharp knife, clean up both parts. In particular, you'll need to remove the support material from under the PVC hose barbs.

  • Test-fit your fan. If all is well, hot glue it to the fan mount.

  • Attach some suitable lengths of 1/4" PVC tubing to the fan. Most hardware stores carry this stuff in the plumbing section. If there are gaps or uneven spots in your printed hose barbs, you may want to seal the edges of the hose with hot glue. Make sure the hoses are long enough to curve back around to your nozzle, and then leave some extra.

  • Affix the fan mount to your Z-stage somehow. I used just a tiny dab of hot glue.

  • Run power to your fan, from any convenient source of 12V DC on your bot. I'm tapping power off the stepper driver that I added for the MakerGear extruder.

  • Run the hoses through the holes in your Z-stage, and around toward the nozzle. Use zip ties to keep them snug against the underside of the Z-stage. You don't want them drooping below nozzle level.

  • Using the printed ring nozzle as a guide, cut the hoses to the right length.

  • Fit the nozzle into place. Again, if the hose barbs aren't making an airtight seal, add some hot glue.

  • Use more zip ties if necessary to keep the nozzle in place, by securing the hoses near it. The nozzle should be centered around your hot-end, and make sure to leave some clearance between it and the nozzle along the whole perimeter. We don't want the nozzle melting!

  • Finally, do a test print! The extra cooling will help the most on parts with thin pieces.

comments.text: Barely any air flow?.... Have you seen the other coolers and how much they blow? If you think a barely noticeable current helps, try it with a "real" cooler and see the difference. This concept is clever, but terribly inefficient. It also looks like you used PLA... Not a good idea by the hotend, use Tglase at the very LEAST to avoid melting. If I see correctly here, you've made a sort of turbine, but whats the point of doing that when it turns air pressure and speed into kinetic energy, when a direct blow is far better in this situation? This isn't a turbo for a car, and using that concept isn't gonna work here. I don't like to be negative, I hate spewing truth all over the place, but fact is, it cant hold a candle to the direct coolers. You also don't want it blowing on the block, that insulation is there for a reason. The idea is to cool the very tip of the nozzle where its extruding hot plastic. Props on the effort... but eeeeh.... no thanks.
comments.author: DevWolf

comments.text: I think you're misunderstanding this design completely, which is funny given the tirade you went on a bit lower down this page railing against people with no engineering knowledge or modeling experience. The point of this design is simply a ring-shaped nozzle. Air comes in the side through a barbed fitting, and exits out the bottom directed to converge at the tip of the nozzle where the plastic is being extruded. I'm going to give you the benefit of the doubt and assume you were confused by the fourth picture from the left, so let me explain that one. It's a fan housing. It blows air with a PC fan into a hose that runs down to the nozzle. Efficient? Not overly. Cheap, easy, and effective? Sure!

comments.text: You may wish to think things through a bit before being so critical. The overhang in the nozzle itself is only an overhand in the most technical sense; it's barely 20 degrees. That's not the one I was mentioning. You'll notice that on the side of the nozzle there is a barbed fitting. That's round. The base of any circle printed in that orientation will have an overhang of greater than 45 degrees for the first portion of the print. That's not such a big deal now, but it was an accomplishment to get good print quality with a home machine in 2011. We've come an incredibly long way since then.

After trying to determine if size problems of inner features on a print were caused by miscalibration of the X or Y axis steps per mm, I came up with this.
It allows the measurement of head move distances by looking at the spacing between voids - that way if there's over or under extrusion, the measurements are of the voids.

Print the test piece.
The square ends are the X axis. The round ends are the Y axis.
Find a matching pair of holes at each end of the piece, where the hole is only barely visible.
Measure the distance between the holes using a micrometer.
The distance should be 100mm. If it isn't, recalibrate the steps per mm on that axis.
Rinse and repeat.

author: lowlight

description.text: Vase modeled in Maya:  Wanted to try my hand at an undulating, twisting, ephemeral form.  It is constantly "in flux".

Provided two different stl files:
  • flux_vase.stl : Has no top or bottom. This is what I printed with in Simplify3D since it handles forms like this fine (nice!).
  • flux_vase_solid.stl : Has a top and bottom, making it a solid volume if your slicer needs it. Note I've not tried to actually print this one.
    • Sliced in Simplify3D & printed on Makerbot Replicator (1) with these settings:
  • 200 micron, 2 shells, no infill, no roof, 4 bottom layers.
  • Natural PLA @ 200 deg, HBP off.
  • No raft, no supports.
  • 90mm/sec print, 120mm/sec travel.
    Took around 5.25 hours.
    • Note if I printed this again I'd use 3 or 4 shells : While this needs no support, if you want it water-tight you'll need more shells to help the extreme angles for the folds in the middle area.

comments.text: You have a file that doesn't have a top or bottom and another file that the top and bottom are solid. Could you make one that has the top open so we can put water in it please? Also I am fairly new with 3D printing and I am unfamiliar with the "shell" terminology to make it water proof. Would you mind giving an updated one that is 3D printable and can hold water?
comments.author: sharonkay

comments.text:
The solid model I provided should work, you just need to tweak your slicer settings. For example, on many silcers (Makerware & Simplify3d are the two I use) you can control how many "top layers" you want: Set that to zero, and print the "solid" vase with zero infill: That'll give you a hollow vase with no top.
When I refer to 'shells', those are the perimeter outlines that go around the exterior of each layer: The more 'shells' you have, the 'thicker' the walls will be. Based on some of the angles on the vase, I'd guess you'd need 4-6 shells (if you have a .4mm nozzle) to make that thing fully water-tight. Also, personally, I wouldn't use PLA (if you are) for anything water-related, since it's (very slowly) bio-degradable. ABS on the other hand would be fine.
If this doesn't make sense I'd be happy to provide more info: What printer and slicer are you using?

a low poly tree created in blender

Inspired by another user's servo adaptor I decided to roll my own after having to hack on his to make it work for my servos.  I was trying to use an MG996R servo in place of the HS-805BB servo for raising and rotating the head/neck of my InMoov build but the other upload was giving me grief trying to get the MG996R inside it.   
Since I was making my own with OpenScad, I thought I would make it parametric so other people could reuse it to convert all sorts of servos to all kinds of other servos.

The STL should work as is to put a MG996R in place of an HS-805BB but you will still need to deal with the difference in horn height. There's a spacer on Thingiverse for that (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:70324). For other servos you'll need to adapt the measurements in the scad file yourself.

comments.text:
I love OpenScad so I felt tempted to download your adapter. However - the piece (despite the pictures) sees me puzzled.
If used as an inset into the standard ServoHolder it lacks the holes for the screws and I can not understand what the angled vertices shold be good for?
Why not create an individual complete replacing ServoHolder for the differing measures including compensation for the servo hight (measure A minus F in hobbyking drawings) so it would fit with with the parts it connects to?
comments.author: juergm

comments.text: Thanks for the constructive criticism.  You make a completely valid points all around.  This part was simply a small evolution of the part I remixed it from. As you said the ideal option would be to remake the ServoHolder in OpenScad but this is more of a quick fix for anyone that already printed and installed the original ServoHolder in the Torso and can't easily get it out but wants to use a smaller servo. Also the servo holder in the head is not a short print either and a tedious disassembly to deal with if you want to replace it with a standard servo version.

author: stevewilkco

description.text:
Spare parts of a canvas chair. Includes the Foot Piece and the Rear Sliding piece. Here are some other pieces for this style chair that you may need: Back Support from CodeCreations
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21805 Folding Chair Hinge from Agger
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:113992

I took the dimensions off of the original broken piece. Printing was done in ABS with 50% infill and no supports. Foot Piece Installation: (Part without the Big Hole)
Hardware needed: (2) 6-32 x 1-1/4 Machine Screws and (2-4) 6-32 Hex Nuts. May need (2) 6-32 x 3/4 Machine Screws OR Small Wood Screws for rear foot piece.
Step 1: Remove existing plastic ware with pliers
Step 2: Remove inset rivet by cutting one end off.(Difficult without proper tools)
Step 3: Follow the existing pattern for placement of inner and outer rods.
Step 4: Insert one Machine Screw per leg and one hex net. You can add washers, but for me it wasn't necessary. Additionally, you may want to add loctite, or glue, to the hex nut, but be sure there is still rotation of the chair leg.
Step 5: If it is a rear foot piece, insert the upright leg, and secure with small wood screw, or drill a hole in the bottom of the foot and use pliers to pull a (SHORTER) machine screw tight to the part with an inserted Hex nut. Rear Sliding Piece Installation: (Part with the Big Hole)
Hardware needed: (2) 6-32 x 1-1/4 Machine Screws and (2) 6-32 Hex Nuts
Step 1: Unscrew the top of the the canvas chair secured from the back(phillips for me). Remove the plastic end cap, arm rest, and seat connection. (You may have to fold the chair slightly)
Step 2: Remove existing plastic ware with pliers
Step 3: Remove inset rivet by cutting one end off.(Difficult without proper tools)
Step 4: Slide the piece down the exposed up-right and follow the existing pattern for placement of inner and outer rods.
Step 5: Insert one Machine Screw per leg and one hex net. Washers optional. Additionally, you may want to add loctite, or glue, to the hex nut, but be sure there is still rotation of the chair leg.
Step 6: Fold the chair slightly and return the bottom canvas connection, the arm connection, and then the top end cap and lastly the back sleeve. Secure with the screw that was originally removed.

I designed this keyboard leg to replace a broken part on a Microsoft Natural Ergonomic Keyboard 4000 v1.0.  In the Comments section, maker Norm Nichols reports that it also works on the Microsoft Multimedia Keyboard.  I have no idea if it will fit other keyboards, but if anyone lets me know what it is and is not compatible with, I'll add that information here.

This is best printed in a tough but slightly flexible material such as ABS or (my favorite) PET, as it needs to be able to flex without snapping.  Snapping when flexed is basically what happened to the original.

This works best when made from a strong but slightly flexible material such as ABS or PET (PETg is my favorite filament for this type of application).  The piece should fit snugly around the connectors.

I needed a revolving door.  So here's a revolving door.

Print 4 Panels, 2 Walls, and one of everything else.
Then push the panels into the slots on the post, stick the spinner through the ceiling and into the hole on the post, put the walls on the base, and put the ceiling and door on top of the walls. Everything should slide together and stick, but you may want to put a touch of glue in various places. (Just don't glue the door to the walls and base!) Then spin the top and watch the door revolve!

title: Case for the Full Graphic Smart LCD Controller with SDcard access and separate button

description.text: This version is derived from wersy's case (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:87250) with the addition of an sdcard access recess but unlike Srek's case (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:195369) I choose to keep the origional separate button so I could print it in a different colour. This is for the http://www.reprapdiscount.com/home/34-full-graphic-smart-lcd-controller.html and its clones I fixed the issues with the button height in the graphics displays adapters currently available from aliexpress where the switch is a little too thick for the origional design. this is a parameter at the start of the.scad file that can be adjusted for your particular board. The photos show a version printed in ABS and because I'm still tuning my setup for ABS its quiality is not as nice as the origional case I printed in PLA but I expect once I get abs tuned it will look better

The files:-
mods_for_display_case_front.stl
mods_for_display_case_back.stl
mods_for_display_case_button.stl
are used to print the case suitable for the smart graphics displays from Aliexpress. To change this you must regenerate from the mods_for_display_case.scad. To use the .scad file you must unzip Case_for_the_Full_Graphic_Smart_LCD_Controller.zip, the origional display case files into the same directory as mods_for_display_case.scad. You can then edit the switch height parameter at the start to adjust the height of the button and the button surround.
You must then export the 3 stl files by uncomenting one part of the case at a time and f6 then export->stl. I print the button narrow side dowm so that the user visible face gets nice and smooth from my glass bed. Doing it this way requires that the printer handles overhangs well. if seems to work well enough with my prusa i3 deravitive but might not for all printers
If its a little daggy arround the flange then a quick trim with a knife is all thats necessary as that part isn't visible to the user anyway.

comments.author: GiveItAll1

comments.text: I use Zbrush to sculpt. It is easily the best program for that kind of stuff. I've tried the Mudbox and a couple of other ones but they seem very intro level on the capabilities. I'm not a power user but that being said, I am still able to sculpt the things that I can imagine without great difficulty. I personally think you could not have chosen a better program to use for digital sculpting. That is for the brute force polygon modeling method. For the more refined modeling method with polygon effeciency in mind I use Maya simply because it had tools similar to the Alias Studio tools that I started out with from school for NURBS surfacing. I switched to poly modeling in Maya. There was a dark time that when I used Form Z but I don't like to talk about it. It was bad.

remixed_from.author: sengelking
remixed_from.title: Simple Replicator enclosure, no laser needed

title: FlashForge / Replicator Front & Side Opening Window Covers for Enclosure

description.text:
See instructions, may need tweaks. Top front clips need better fingerholds (installs easy, hard to get out). I wanted to enclose my FlashForge printer to help with heat for ABS printing, so after looking at some other techniques, I of course had to do my own thing. It's similar to some of the others. I liked the idea of recessed "windows" that fit within the opening (instead of over them). The windows are intended to be cut by laser, but you could do it by hand.
Check Dimensions

I'm not sure how standard these things are, so if you're laser cutting, try printing the PDF first and see if it fits.
Support Me Please

If you like my stuff please check out my Lego R2-D2's blog at http://L3-G0.com or L3-G0's Youtube, and please tweet or Facebook a link to his page. He's cool and every visitor helps support my maker habit, thanks!

I couldn't get soupaman's clips to print, and tweaked most of the other stuff. I have access to a laser cutter, so I had to make a PDF that the laser could cut.
Check Dimensions

I'm not sure how standard these things are, so if you're laser cutting, try printing the PDF first and see if it fits. I used 1/8" acrylic. If you have a different thickness you may need to tweak the plastic bits.
Parts

• Two outer windows for the left & right sides, cut by hand or laser. I have a notch in one because I have a clip-on light (Fred Meyer) on the printer
  • One front window, also cut by hand or laser, but laser's probably way easier
  • 8 round side clips (both front & back), 4 each for the side panels.
  • 1 handle/clasp for front window bottom
  • 2 spring clasps for top of front window.. I need to make these better, it's easy to put window in, but hard to pull out.
  • You'll also need 2 springs for the spring clasps. Mine are 1/4" X 13/32" compression (nominal)
  • 2 #8x32 screws, 1/2" or so. Similar metric size would work if you tap the hole.
    • Assembly:

• Cut side windows by hand or laser on 1/8" stock. Use SideWindow.pdf or use the "dimensions" file for by-hand.
  • Check the fit of the windows. My side windows didn't fit perfectly and I had to file the sides. I narrowed the PDF so it should be better for you. but have no need to recut them myself.
  • Print round clips, 8 fronts & 8 backs (use the two 8x files). I did not need raft or supports.
  • If you care about the dragons, there are 2 on the bottom and one on the left and one on the right when in position. Make sure to use the right fronts to face the right direction (if you care) when installed.
  • Attach them to the window, gluing the center of the back post to the front (but letting them move on the window). They're a tad loose, so you could print the fronts at 99% scale or something.
  • Side windows attach by rotating the clips so the window slides in, then rotating the clips back out to hold it in place.
  • I installed the side windows at the same time as the clips so that I could ensure that the clips pressed tightly against the frame without being too tight.
  • Print front window. Again mine was too fat by a hair, but I did not adjust the PDF.
  • Print both halves of the bottom clasp. I didn't use a raft or supports.
  • It's designed to attach with two #8x32 screws. I had to tap the thread of the clasp.
  • Screw the clasp to the front window. I had to file the inside a bit as it was too tight to be useful. The front window should slide down over the front frame.
  • Print the spring clips (2 of them). I used raft & supports. Supports are a pain to dig out, but it was easiest to print them.
  • Clean up the spring clips, trying not to trim off the little retaining knobs on the inside.
  • Put a spring inside each clip and snap them to the top of the window. Hopefully they then push up when you let them go.
  • Put the bottom of the front window over the bottom plywood, depress the two clips and snap the top over the top plywood edge.
    • Notes

• My window sizes aren't exact, I used Davecc's dimensions for the sides, but they were smidgen too fat and I had to file it down. I'm guessing that we're using English approximates for Metric measurements. Either that or there're differences in machine's tolerances. My dimensions file is a hair smaller because of that.
  • Something's messed up with the poly's of the bottom front clasp. It works OK though so it uses .00001g more than needed but isn't worth me trying to clean up the file.
  • Ditto the inside of the screw threads acts oddly and will need cleaned out.
  • It may be easier to shove the top springy clips in with one indent sideways and then the other over the plastic.
  • I tried to add some photos of how the parts connect. Pretty straightforward to me, but then I planned it, so....
  • I used a sharpie to color the raised bits black.

author: Rudster

title: ID Card Holder with L3 Logo

description.text:
ID card holder with the L-3 Communications logo in a separate STL file.  
The ID card dimensions are same as a standard credit card of driver's license.

Printed in PLA using Simplify 3D.
For the holder...Layer: 0.2mm; Infill: 50%; Supports: 15%, 45 degrees, 0.3mm horizontal separation, 0.2mm expansion.
For the logo...Layer: 0.1mm; Infill: 100% The holder and logo were both printed face down, so the smooth surfaces would face out. The holder STL is oriented face down, but the logo will have to be flipped over to print face down. Logo glued onto the holder.

title: Electronics Enclosure & Cover for Lulzbot Taz 4

description.text: This is the electronics enclosure and cover that come's with the Lulzbot Taz 4.  I upgraded my printer from the Taz 3 to the Taz 4 and this was the only component I was missing since It's not available for purchase.  I decided to design it myself in Autodesk Inventor.  I plan on using heatset inserts on the enclosure for the places where the metal version has threaded holes.   I haven't had a chance to print it yet but once I do I will upload photos and the settings I used to print it.  If you print it before that let me know how it turns out.
